awd_titl_txt: Global Dynamics of Nonlinear Dispersive Evolution Equations and Spectral Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims at understanding the propagation of waves in a wide sense. On the one hand, the PI will investigate the behavior of waves in space, as they interact nonlinearly with themselves and matter over large space-time scales. The ultimate goal is to explain how the  energy, which is stored in a wave undergoing a nonlinear dynamical evolution, ultimately  splits  into  quantized pieces and a wave "at the horizon". The latter refers to energy, possibly of large size, which  is infinitely spread out and does not interact with anything in a noticeable fashion. In contrast with this macroscopic behavior, the project also aims at understanding the behavior of waves on the microscopic scale, such as in crystals or quasi-crystals. The goal is to explain  transitions from an insulating state to that of a conductor, which these materials may exhibit as they undergo changes on the molecular level. Such changes may occur  through the insertion of impurities, or changes in the environment. Both the macroscopic as well as the microscopic behavior of waves is of crucial importance to science and engineering, and profoundly affects our daily modern lives. Modern communication relies on waves transmitted over large distances both in space but also along glass fiber cables. For the latter the properties of the material are crucial and both nonlinear effects as well as aforementioned microscopic phenomena decide the suitability  of the underlying medium. 

More technically speaking, the PI intends to further investigate the rigorous mathematical theory of focusing dispersive semilinear evolution equations. A major open problem is to analyze  the resolution of any solution into moving solitons and radiation. Some success has been achieved in recent years on this important problem, but for nonintegrable equations we are far from a satisfactory understanding. The PI is currently involved in the study of this problem in the dissipative setting in which some damping is added to the equation. The Hamiltonian setting appears to be very difficult at the moment, especially in the subcritical regime. The methods involved derive from dynamical systems, invariant manifold theory, and dispersive PDEs. The quantum mechanical problems alluded in the previous paragraph belong to the area of Anderson localization. Together with his long-standing collaborator Michael Goldstein at Toronto, but also with young collaborators which are joining the field, the PI intends to bring the body of techniques which were developed over the past 20 years  based on large deviation estimates, the avalanche principle, semi-algebraic sets, and harmonic analysis such as (pluri)subharmonic functions and the Cartan estimate, to bear on both linear and nonlinear problems in dynamical systems and spectral theory.  Ultimately, the goal here is also to better describe the behavior of wave propagation in disordered media.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The PI has been investigating the evolution of nonlinear waves describing natural phenomena relating to propagation of waves in media. The nonlinearity refers arises through interaction of the wave with the medium, or through self-interaction of the wave with itself. Elementary particles in quantum mechanics appear as special solutions of such equations, with the one of lowest energy singled out as a ground state of the system. In order for the mathematical description of nature to be meaningful, it is of paramount importance to establish stability of this groundstate. Stability here refers to the property that disturbances of small size or energy do not significantly change the main features of the observed phenomena. Indeed, such small disturbances are ubiquituous in nature and a major task of scientists and engineers is to prepare and guard for them. For example, data transmission over long distances is invariably prone to the accumulation of errors. On the one hand, technology needs to keep these errors small and on the other hand, be able to function despite of them.

The PI established stability of special solutions to two types of nonlinear wave equations. First, in joint work with Krieger (EPFL) and Miao (Wuhan), he proved the stability of ground state wave maps from two spatial dimensions into the two-sphere. The novelty of this result lies with the fact that perturbations are allowed to be non-symmetric under rotations. Perviously, all known results required absence of angular dependence. The techniques allowing for this advance are based on earlier work by the PI from more than a decade ago aimed at proving the Price law of wave decay on the background of a Schwarzschild black hole. This long-standing conjecture in General Relativity required several years of analysis by the PI and others, leading to the development of asymptotic techniques of semi-classical analysis in the regime of two or three small parameters. It was precisely this type of linear analysis that reappeared as the key in the nonlinear result by the PI with Krieger and Miao. This work took two years to complete and its final publication has been delayed by COVID. The PI and his collaborators plan to submit a final version in book format this year.

A second stability result was obtained by the PI jointly with Luehrmann (TAMU) and concerns the asymptotic stability of a special solution to the so-called sine-Gordon equation. The latter is an example of a nonlinear wave equation in classical field theory, an area of physics originating in electrodynamics and gravitation but then subsequently undergoing quantization. From the classical  point of view, the one-dimensional sine-Gordon equation describes a so-called chiral field under the simplest rotational symmetry, while in geometry it had appeared much earlier, in fact about 160 years ago as a compatibility condition between the metric and the curvature on a pseudo-sphere. The sine-Gordon equation has numerous special symmetries which renders it completely integrable and thus amenable to a highly developed body of methods such as the inverse scattering transform. With Luehrmann the PI succeeded in proving the asymptotic stability of kink solutions under small odd perturbations. The method of proof does not directly use the techniques of completely integrable equations but rather proceeeds by a perturbative analysis. The motivation for seeking such a proof method lies with other models of classical field theory such as phi4. The latter is not completely integrable and it is still unknown whether the kink solution is asymptotically stable even under odd perturbations.

The intellectual merit of the PI's major publications lies with their novetly in both technique and its application. It remains to be seen if other related fundamental questions can be addressed by similar arguments.

The broader impact lies with the importance of analyzing and describing wave propagation for the purposes of science and engineering. In fact, modern society relies heavily on the safe transmission of vast amounts of information and thus on sophisticated mathematics. The PI's research adds to the body of mathematics needed to describe and ultimately harness fundamental forces of nature. In addition, the PI has trained students at both the undergraduate and graduate levels, as well as postdoctoral scholars in the mathematical disciplines needed to compete internationally in the competitive scientific arena.
